post.title: How Couples Meet in the Age of the Internet
post.content:encoded:
A study compares 1995 to 2017, showing that things have changed

“So, how did you meet?”

Every couple gets asked this question at some point.

For 5,421 study participants, the ones asking that question were a team of sociology researchers from Stanford and the University of New Mexico.

Compiling data from those surveys, they published the results in a study with the very un-sexy title, “Disintermediating your friends: How online dating in the United States displaces other ways of meeting.” [1]

As implied by this title, friends have become “disintermediated” as the primary way for couples to meet, as more people turn to online apps and dating sites.

I gathered the data presented in Table 1 of this study to make a basic graph that shows the gist of all this:

In 2017, 39% of couples in met online, compared to only 2% in 1995 who presumably were early adopters of AOL or met in some manner that resembled Napoleon Dynamite’s brother Kip. That big increase in online matchmaking implies a decrease in meeting through friends or other real-life scenarios. The odd exception to this is meeting at bars and restaurants, which is the only other category to increase since 1995.

It should be noted that this study was only inclusive of heterosexual couples, and results may vary for non-heterosexual couples. Also, since participants were asked the open-ended question, “how did you meet,” the researchers had to categorize the responses from written out explanations. That means there is some overlap in categories due to responses such as “we were friends at school,” etc.

The researchers have been apparently gathering data on this question since 2009, and it is publicly available here. Unfortunately, 2017 is the latest date for which data is available at this time, but I hope they’ve been tracking this through the pandemic because it will be interesting to see how all the social distancing and social not-distancing-anymore relapse has affected things.

  1. Rosenfeld, et al. Disintermediating your friends: How online dating in the United States displaces other ways of meeting. PNAS. 2019, 116 (36) 17753–17758. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1908630116
